page.title: 02History of Kirtlington part1
page.content: Local History- The name Kirtlington is thought to originate from CYRTLALINGTON meaning "The town of Cyrtla's people", Cyrtla presumably being a tribal chief. Kirtlington was originally in the counties of Wessex/Mercia. In Roman times Kirtlington was a place of great importance having two Roman roads, Akeman Street which crossed the Portway (now the Heyford Road). Roman camps were nearby. Traces of Avesditch (ash bank or wattle bank) still remain and this was probably a line of fortification and a boundary. In the Domesday Survey of 1086 Kirtlington is described as a Royal Manor, and mention is made of tolls which were paid. It is not certain who the first owners of Kirtlington Manor (actually in Northbrook) were although it is likely that Robert D'Oyly, Governor of Oxford held a great part of it.
